titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. General Varnum called upon me this morning, and had some conversation with me on the subject of public affairs— He read to me part of a letter from Washington, which states that it was circulated there, and had been asserted by a federalist with the offer of a bet, that Mr: Madison had made me the offer of a foreign embassy, provided I would join his party— I told him there was no foundation in the report— That I had never had any conversation with Mr: Madison, either about the next Election, or about political party— That Mr: Madison had never made me any promises, and I was never
never inclined to receive promises from him had he been disposed to make me any.— I told him that Mr: Giles had occasionally mentioned to me that both Mr: Jefferson & Mr: Madison would be gratified by receiving from federalists support to the Administration— And that I had taken occasion to tell him that there was and would be nothing in the gift of the President of the United States, which I wanted or wished— And that any support they had received or should receive from me would be from public considerations, and no personal motive whatsoever. I dined at Mr: James Prince’s—the Marshal— Judges Cushing & Davis; with several other Gentlemen were there— Mr: Brooks, Mr: Story—Sheriff’s Allen and Cutler & Mr: Shaw— I called afterwards at Mr: Emerson’s & saw him— Dr: Dexter was with him.— I took home with me my lectures, which Mr: Emerson has had over Winter— Attended the club afterwards at Dr: Eliot’s— It was tolerably well attended.

2. Mr: Isaac Smith called upon me this morning, and pass’d an hour with me— Spent the Evening with the Ladies at Dr: Danforth junrs: with a company of Ladies and Gentlemen— Mr: Wheaton’s Resolutions were this day adopted by the House of Representatives; and this afternoon the House came to the choice of a Senator of the United States, to serve from the 3d: of March next; when my time would expire— The votes were for James Lloyd junr: 248. for J. Q. Adams 213. for Laban Wheaton 1. Of course Mr Lloyd is chosen—

3. The appointment of Mr: Lloyd, as a Senator of the United States, in my stead, after the 3d: of March next, was this day confirmed by the Senate—21. votes for Mr: Lloyd, and 17. for me.— Spent the day at home, excepting a short time at the Athenaeum— And at several Bookseller’s shops, where I ordered a number of books.

4. My father came into Town this morning, and dined with the Agricultural Society at Dr: Dexter’s.— In the afternoon, I went with him out to Quincy, and took George with us— I wrote one or two letters; and a little of my 30th: Lecture.
5. Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day— Communion day— The Summer heats have begun, and this was one of the warmest of the year— I read two Lectures of Porteus on St: Matthew’s gospel.

6. Artillery Election— Returned to Boston, with my son John, and brought Mrs: T. B. Adams in to her Sister Foster’s. I had an invitation to the public dinner, but did not go— There was a severe thunder-shower, which began soon after dinner time, and continued untill about 7. in the Evening, when the weather cleared away again.— Catherine went to tea, with Miss Danforth; where I called for her between 8 and 9— The excessive heat prevented me from writing, almost entirely.

7. Mr: S. A. Otis called upon me this morning; and told me that he thought our Legislature had done a very bad thing, by not re-electing a very good Senator—meaning me— That he was very much mortified at it— And his Son (H. G. Otis—President of the Senate) was equally so— That he did every thing in his power, but could not prevent it— That the tide ran too strong— The Essex Junto were omnipotent— All this I understand—perfectly well— I was part of this morning at my Office— The remainder of the day at home, writing, for my Lectures— Walk, morning and Evening in the Mall— Mr: Ripley was here this afternoon.

8. Walking this morning in the Mall I met Genl: H. Jackson, who express’d himself very favourably of the principles contained in my letter to Mr: Otis— I found on going into State-Street that Mr: Wheaton’s anti-embargo Resolutions were yesterday adopted by the Senate— I therefore this day sent a letter to the two houses with my resignation of my Seat as a Senator of the United States; which I enclosed to Mr: H. G. Otis, and left at his house, he not being at home— I attended the club, this Evening, at Mr: Edward Gray’s— It was well attended.

9. Mr: Lloyd was chosen this day by the Legislature to supply the vacancy in the Senate of the United States, occasioned by my resignation. I went this morning to a Mr: Howe’s to examine a Rumford kitchen, and to bespeak some of the pieces for it which he makes— At my Office in the afternoon— Dr: Welsh called and had some conversation with me before dinner— Evening at a party at Mr: S. A. Otis’s— His son’s family were there, but not himself.

div.p: 10. I walked to Cambridge this morning— Heard a Lecture from Dr: Waterhouse, and at 10. Read my Lecture 28.— The division of Students who were to have declaimed at 2. came to me, and informed me that they were not prepared for speaking this day— I therefore returned to Boston before dinner— Evening with the Ladies at Dr: Welsh’s.

11. Commenced this morning the rough sketch of my Lecture 31. And was busily engaged upon it all the former part of the day— Also in the afternoon, untill my brother came in for me from Quincy— I went out with him to my father’s; and took my son George, with me.

12. The day was foul— I went to meeting however this morning, and heard Mr: Chickering of Dedham— The afternoon, and most of the Evening I employed in reading—Bolingbroke’s life by Goldsmith; and some parts of Bolingbroke’s own writings— Also Several of Dr: Johnson’s Tracts.

13. Return’d to Boston this morning in the Stage with George— Mr: Casaux the french Consul at Portsmouth called upon me— I was engaged the whole day at my drudgery— Walk in the Evening with the Ladies in the Mall. Paid a visit also to Mr: S. Dexter.

14. My application to the composition of my lectures almost overpowers me. I walked however in the Mall this morning, and Evening— Went this afternoon with the Ladies and heard Dr: Danforth junr: deliver a discourse before the humane Society; at the Chapel Church— My brother came in to town; dined with us, and took Catherine Johnson with him out to Quincy; to spend some days at my father’s.

15. Took a Morning and Evening walk in the Mall And went to the N. England Insurance office before dinner— Call’d at Mr: Jos: Hall’s Office— Attended the Club at Dr: Howard’s— The remainder of the day I was steadily engaged upon my lecture.

16. I called this morning upon Mr: Jackson the College Treasurer, and before dinner at the Banks— Walked in the Evening, with my wife and children in the Mall; and afterwards alone— The rest of the day I was engaged upon my lecture— We are making alterations in our house, and putting up a Rumford kitchen.

div.p: 17. I walked to Cambridge, and read my 29th: Lecture— After which I went in to the philosophy chamber, and heard a Lecture from Mr: Farrar, the professor of natural and experimental philosophy— His subject was Galvanism— He made his experiments upon several martyred frogs; and we took the shock from the battery and pile, and the flash across the eyes— I do not find that the facts of this new discovery have been much increased— I dined with Dr: Waterhouse, and at 2. O’Clock attended the Declamation. It was indifferent, and the speakers fewer in number than usual— I rode with Dr: Waterhouse to the Marine hospital at Charlestown; which appears to be a good institution, and in a very good condition— Walked home over Charlestown Bridge— Met some military companies who were celebrating the day— The anniversary of the Battle of Bunker’s Hill— In the Evening I had symptoms of that slight fever which has frequently returned upon me at the close of the Spring, and beginning of Summer.

18. We had a storm of wind and rain the whole day, which confined me altogether to the house— I employed it chiefly in reading, but began upon my 32d: Lecture— Catherine Johnson expected to have returned this day from Quincy, but did not— Our children are all somewhat unwell— The youngest suffering severely with teething.

19. The storm continued the greatest part of this day; but I heard Mr: Lowell this morning, and Mr: Ripley this afternoon, at Mr: Emerson’s— At home I read two Sermons of Massillon’s Petit Carême; preached before Louis XV. in his minority. The rest of the day I was engaged in writing on my Lecture.— Mr: Shaw called to see us this afternoon.

20. We saw Dr: Welsh for our youngest child, who is very sick— I walk’d morning, Noon and Evening— Continued my writing, all the time that I could command— Finished my Lecture 32— Met Mr: Degrand in the Mall— He came home, and spent an hour with me— The weather has been so cold that we have had fires these three days.

21. Our boy Charles is this day somewhat recovered— I pass’d the forenoon at my Office— Called upon Mr: Perrin May, in consequence of Mr: Buchanan’s letter— Wrote to Mr: Buchanan— My brother came in from Quincy with Catherine Johnson. Spent the afternoon engaged upon my lectures.

22. Morning at home, reading, and writing at my lectures— Afternoon at my Office; where I found both Mr: Everett and Mr: Gallison.— Mrs: T. B. Adams and her Sister Foster were here this morning.— Club this Evening at Mr: Smith’s— But it was very thinly attended.

23. I spent again the day entirely at home, reading and writing for my lecture— This afternoon Mr: S. A. Otis and Mr: Bradley called upon me— Mr: Bradley is going to New-York and the Springs— And leaves town to-morrow morning— I took my usual morning and Evening walks in the Mall— The latter with the ladies.

24. I had prepared to walk to Cambridge this morning, and deliver a Lecture there; but a heavy and steady rain from six in the morning untill noon prevented me— About 12. O’Clock it held up, and I went immediately Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Heard the Declamation at 2. It was better than that of the last week— I returned home immediately afterwards, and pass’d the remainder of the day, reading for my lectures— I wrote very little— Dr: Welsh was here this Evening, to our child Charles, who is again very ill.

25. My father came into Town this morning, and went to dine at Mr: Preble’s at Watertown, with Mr: Quincy and the Trustees of the agricultural Society— My Mother also came in, and dined with us— In the afternoon I went out with her to Quincy, and took John with us— It being John’s turn. Going out we broke one of the bolts in our Chaise, which we were obliged to have repaired at Roxbury— It was consequently almost ten at Night when we reached Quincy.

26. An indifferent Night—John being very restless and unwell— Heard Mr: Whitney in the morning; and Mr: Page of Braintree, afternoon— Mr: Black, and Mr: T. Greenleaf with their Ladies were with us in the Evening— I read in Gibbon, and in Shaftesbury— Part of his Essay on Wit and Humour— Wrote however but little.

27. Another ill night— Owing chiefly this time to the heat— It kept me so long in bed this morning that I was too late for the Stage— My father’s boy Job, drove me home in a Chaise— The day was of such excessive heat, that I could not write— But I read—Heron’s preface to Junius, and Swift’s Journal to Stella— Mr: C. Foster was here this Evening—which closed with a severe thunder shower— This afternoon, Mr: Munro the printer called upon me with a manuscript history of Miranda’s expedition; by a Mr: Biggs; which he has thoughts of printing, and concerning which he wants my opinion.

28. I spent the day at home, excepting the morning and Evening walk in the Mall— Mr: Ripley was here from Cambridge, and dined with us— Mrs: Welsh here this afternoon— I was somewhat unwell; and wrote not so much as I ought to have done.

29. Pass’d the day partly at home, and partly at my Office— Attended the club this Evening at Dr: Spooner’s— But he had mistaken his turn, and thought the club was this Evening at Mr: Smith’s— Dr: Dexter was the only other member there— But Mr: Nicholls of Philadelphia and Mr: Starks of this town were there.

30. Mr: and Mrs: Quincy called to pay us a visit this forenoon— Catherine Johnson went with Mr: Ripley to Concord, and returned this Evening— Harriet Welsh here this afternoon— We went home with her— I was at my Office part of the morning— Began my 33d: lecture— Continued reading Swift’s Journal.

Day— Rise usually about 6 in the morning— Read four chapters in the Bible—write my journal of the preceding day. Walk half an hour in the Mall— Breakfast— Read— Write—or attend at my Office untill 1. Sometimes untill 2 or 3. Dine— Read—write—and attend again at my Office untill dark— Half-an-hour’s walk again in the Mall. Sup between 9 and 10.— Bed about 11. Wednesday Evening’s at Club— Saturday & Sunday often at Quincy.
